docs.title: Welcome to Kube The Home
docs.text:
Hello, I am a Cloud Platform / DevOps Engineer that is very passionate about self-hosting.

Under the name Kube The Home I am developing Helm Charts / Applications and other, that I feel like are missing in the world of self-hostable applications.

docs.title: Aspire Dashboard
docs.text:
The Dotnet Aspire Dashboard is a leightweight Open Telemetry Dashboard that has mainly been developed to aid in local development. It can help displaying Logs, Metrics and Traces.

As it is fairly leightweight it a great tool to use in small Homeserver setups, as it has a way smaller footprint than the Kube-Prometheus-Stack.

If you want to deploy the Aspire Dashboard to your Kubernetes Cluster, you can use the following Helm Chart.

Installing the Helm Chart.

# Adding the Repository
helm repo add aspire-dashboard https://kube-the-home.github.io/aspire-dashboard-helm/

# Installing the Chart
helm install my-aspire-dashboard aspire-dashboard/aspire-dashboard

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
As the Dashboard was not developed for this usecase the authentication options are a bit inconvenient.

To log-in to the Dashboard you need an authentication token, which at the moment can only be found in the application logs.

docs.title: Example Values
docs.text:
ui:
    ingress:
        enabled: true
        host: aspire.example.com
        annotations: {}
        tls:
            - hosts:
                - aspire.example.com
              secretName: aspire-tls
env:
    # Setting ApiKey to be the main method of authentication
    # for ingestion
    - name: DASHBOARD__OTLP__AUTHMODE
      value: "ApiKey"
    # Setting the API Key otel applications would need to set
    # to ingest metrics
    - name: DASHBOARD__OTLP__PRIMARYAPIKEY
      value: "aspire"

docs.title: Generic Application
docs.text:
This Helm Chart can be used to deploy an generic Application. The values you can use can be found on Github.

Installing the Helm Chart.

# Adding the Repository
helm repo add generic https://kube-the-home.github.io/generic-helm/

# Installing the Chart
helm install my-generic generic/generic

docs.title: Kanboard
docs.text:
This Chart can be used to deploy Kanboard.

Installing the Helm Chart.

# Adding the Repository
helm repo add kanboard https://kube-the-home.github.io/kanboard-helm/

# Installing the Chart
helm install my-kanboard kanboard/kanboard

docs.title: Current restrictions
docs.text:
• Persistence is not setup yet
  • External Databases cannot be used at the moment

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
A basic example for your values.yaml.

ingress:
    enabled: true
    host: example.com

A basic example for your values.yaml using tls.

ingress:
    enabled: true
    host: exmple.com
    tls:
    - hosts:
        - example.com
        secretName: kanboard-tls

A basic example to using this Chart with ArgoCD.

apiVersion: argoproj.io/v1alpha1
kind: Application
metadata:
  name: kanboard
  namespace: argocd
  finalizers:
  - resources-finalizers.argocd.argoproj.io
spec:
  project: default
  revisionHistoryLimit: 1
  destination:
    server: https://kubernetes.default.svc
    namespace: kanboard
  syncPolicy:
    syncOptions:
      - CreateNamespace=true
    automated:
      prune: true
      allowEmpty: true
      selfHeal: true
  source:
    repoURL: https://kube-the-home.github.io/kanboard-helm/
    targetRevision: 0.1.2
    chart: kanboard
    helm:
      valuesObject:
        ingress:
          enabled: true
          host: example.com

docs.title: Skooner
docs.text:
Skooner is a Kubernetes Dashboard that aims to help you understand and manage your cluster. If you want to take a look at it's source code, it can be found on Github.

The source code for the helm chart to deploy skooner can be found on Github as well.

Installing Skooner with the Helm Chart.

# Adding the Repository
helm repo add skooner https://kube-the-home.github.io/skooner-helm/

# Installing the Chart
helm install my-skooner skooner/skooner

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
If you do not specify any external authentication you need to get the access token from the respective Kubernetes Secret.

kubectl describe secret skooner-secret -n <your_skooner_namespace>

docs.title: Hint
docs.text: Setting up external authentication is not yet possible in the current helm chart version.

docs.title: Example Values
docs.text:
ingress:
    enabled: true
    annotations:
        cert-manager.io/cluster-issuer: letsencrypt-dns01-issuer
    host: skooner.example.com
    tls:
    - hosts:
        - skooner.example.com
      secretName: skooner-tls
resources:
    requests:
        memory: "100Mi"
        cpu: "50m"
    limits:
        memory: "150Mi"
        cpu: "100m"
